reviewText:
This is more a mixed review than a negative one.

I bought Out There because it looked similar to FTL, but without the tedium of combat, and in that respect it did not disappoint. Like the starship Voyager, you jump from system to system trying to replenish limited resources, and along the way you meet alien lifeforms and learn new technologies that increase your chances of reaching home. I think the game aptly portrays the feeling of isolation in space, from the ambient soundtrack to the uneasy log entries of the protagonist, a lone astronaut who wakes from cryo-sleep to find himself far across the galaxy.

However, in going from FTL to Out There, I seem to have traded one form of monotony for another. Drilling rocky planets yields iron to repair your hull, but landing on and leaving those planets costs additional fuel. Probing gas giants yields fuel necessary to travel from system to system, but orbiting those planets damages your ship's hull. If either resource (or oxygen) reaches zero, your session ends. Drill, probe, drill, probe. From my experience so far- about three hours- I'd say this routine forms the bulk of each session, which I personally find uninteresting.

There never seems to be enough space to really exploit the technologies you learn on most ship types. Each technology takes up one slot, and most of the ships I've seen so far have no more than a dozen total. Not to mention, around five of those slots will always be taken up by your most essential ship systems. In addition, each unique element / resource takes up its own slot regardless of how little you have of each, and some technologies require multiple elements for construction.  Keep in mind the technologies you learn each session are randomized, so you won't know which metals you'll need at the outset, either. Often I just didn't bother with technology so I could stockpile the three basic necessities, since each slot only stacks up to twenty, and you often need more.

When you meet alien lifeforms, you're usually presented with a choice of Approve or Disapprove, but because you don't know the languages spoken, and because translated words don't carry over from session to session, you may as well flip a coin unless you're writing down all the words you learn on the side. The other events with choices feel equally arbitrary, though I acknowledge this was also built into the design of FTL and may not faze everyone.

In short, if the premise and feeling of the game are what interest you, and the above issues don't bother you, there's a good chance you'll enjoy Out There. If what you're looking for is mechanical depth and varied gameplay, I'd caution you to take a closer look before buying.

Out There: Ω Edition is a resource management rogue-like game which recently released on Steam after huge success on mobile platforms. In Out There: Ω Edition you play as an astronaut who has just woken up from cryogenic stasis on a journey from Earth to Ganymede, you quickly realise you've gone horribly off course and you're nowhere near your destination, you're out there. You must carefully manage your fuel, oxygen and hull in order to stay alive in an unexplored galaxy, along the way you will not only find remnants of the human race who have mysteriously vanished but you will also find alien races and alien artifacts never before seen by man. Out There: Ω Edition is a story about the survival of one man who is way out of his depth on a journey that shouldn't have taken place.

This game has a fair few similarities to FTL: Faster Than Light, in fact it's these similarities that made me buy the game, so you'll see me compare the two games a couple of times over the course of the review. I'm a huge fan of anything Space related and this title did not disappoint

+Gorgeous art style
+Everything in the game is well designed, in particular the ships and the alien life forms
+There are several different ships, each coming with pros and cons meaning each ship has a unique play style
+Usually when you jump to a new star system you get a journal entry/mini text adventure which all have great stories but they're let down by the writer's knowledge of English (I'll come back to that later)
+The galaxy is procedurally generated each time you play so you'll never see the same galaxy twice
+Interesting storyline with an interesting yet mysterious protagonist
+Outstanding (even outstanding doesn't do it justice) soundtrack that even rivals that of FTL
+Great gameplay based around resource management, kind of like FTL with more resources and no combat
+The game has no combat, a bold move that work fantastically, fighting to survive against the environment is much more interesting than fighting to survive against hostile life forms
+As you get further into a run you begin unlocking more advanced technologies to help you get further
+Abandoned ships always seem to turn up just as your ship becomes obsolete which is perfect
+When you encounter alien life forms you often learn parts of their language
+You frequently come across mysterious alien materials and artifacts which often provide ways of improving your ship
+It's impossible to see everything this game has to offer in one run so you're definitely going to come back for more

+/-When something goes wrong, such as your Hydrogen probe being destroyed, it's incredibly unlikely that you're gonna make it since when something goes wrong in this game EVERYTHING goes wrong

-The game is riddled with poor grammar and spelling mistakes which really takes away from the fantastic story in this game, in all fairness the Dev is foreign and English is probably his/her second language but I still don't see why they couldn't have had someone proof read the game

Verdict:
9

Despite the game's numerous spelling errors and grammatical errors this is a fantastic resource management game with a gorgeous art style and fantastic design.

El K.

reviewText:
In 2014, developer Mi-Clos Studio released Out There, a space exploration title for iOS and Android devices. The game was a critical hit, winning awards and gaining rave reviews across the board, with praise for the game’s story and depth. Out There was commercially successful too, selling over 250,000 copies worldwide.

Now the French developer released the acclaimed mobile title for PC, Mac, and Linux, with a wealth of new features and content available. Mi-Clos Studio is also making the new version, titled Out There: Omega Edition, free for any buyers of the original mobile-only build. Gamers who had yet to play the title now have the chance to encounter Out There beyond its mobile beginnings.

Out There is a space-based roguelike, placing a single player into the role of an astronaut who has become lost in an unknown part of the universe. The astronaut must travel to different stars, collecting fuel, oxygen and mineral supplies to try and survive. The end goal is to reach a distant system that promises to reveal secrets about not only the astronaut’s destiny, but the fate of mankind. Players face a procedurally-generated journey from system to system, meaning that each playthrough is different.

It is all to easy to compare Out There to FTL: Faster Than Light, another space-based roguelike. There are, however, a number of differences between the two games. Most importantly, Out There is devoid of combat, and players will not face firefights against opposing spacecraft. Although this may make it seem like players are in for an easy ride, the opposite is true. Indeed, Out There may well be crueler than the Subset Games-developed title.

Out There’s gameplay is entirely based around vulnerability and survival. Players are not able to rely on firepower to escape dangerous situations, and the bulk of the gameplay is instead focused around resource management. Keeping tabs on fuel, air, and hull stability is essential, with different elements repairing or refilling the Fuel, Oxygen, and Hull meters. These elements can be found by mining ore-rich planets to repair the hull, probing gas giants for hydrogen and helium for fuel, and landing on garden planets to refill oxygen supplies.

In a strange way, this means that the game almost plays out like the galaxy exploration mini-games of the Mass Effect series, particularly Mass Effect 2. As a result, if players found the planet-probing moments of Bioware’s series less-than-enthralling, then Out There might not be entertaining. The majority of the early gameplay is made up of three different proactive gameplay moments: sending probes for fuel, mining ore planets, and landing on garden planets. This worked incredibly well on mobile platforms, but home computer players may be left wanting more.

Thankfully, there is plenty to keep players occupied beyond the actual proactive gameplay itself. Out There plays almost as a minimalist adventure story, with text boxes revealing the inner thoughts of the astronaut and locations and events he discovers. Players will also be met with binary choices along the way, such as how to react to unknown creatures and objects in the void. The results can go two ways, rewarding players with additional material and items, or damaging the ship.

The additional items add even more tough choices for players to face. Each new module for the ship, such as shield generators to decease hull damage, takes up space in the cargo hold. Adding a new tool will mean there is less space for fuel, minerals, and oxygen. Players will have to make the decision about what elements must be dropped, and whether new modules are worth keeping over mineral supplies.

The player will also be given the chance to transfer over to new ships, abandoning the human-built craft for alien designs. These ships contain spacefaring tools of their own, as well as upgrades in cargo space – as long as the player is able to repair different parts of the alien vessel. Meanwhile, the player can also meet bizarre monoliths out in the void, granting players with new locations to discover and further developing the game’s story.

It’s not just alien craft that the player discovers, either, as Out There’s garden planets often contain life of their own. Mi-Clos has created a number of bizarre alien races for the player to make contact with. As the player meets and interacts with other races, they gain more and more alien vocabulary, and can slowly begin deciphering the unfamiliar language. Successful negotiations with sentient beings have their own rewards, with new items and the rare and vital Omega element, capable of fixing any of the three main ship components.

The brief meetings with alien races only intensify the feeling of isolation that Out There provides. Mi-Clos Studio’s title is incredibly successful in creating a sense of loneliness, meaning that every moment of contact with another race seems extremely important for the astronaut’s wellbeing. Out There nails down the idea of the cosmos being a dangerous and expansive void, which is lost all-too often in other spaced-based games. In terms of science fiction video games, this is 2001: A Space Odyssey to FTL’s original Star Trek.

The title has plenty of influence from science fiction of days gone by, particularly in terms of the graphical style. Out There has a pulp sci-fi feel, comparable to old-school sci-fi comics, and the vibrant color palette includes Hotline Miami-esque neon-soaked moments to create a varied and complex universe. It works well with the sparse writing, and marries brilliantly with the game’s ambient electronic soundtrack, created by Antichamber composer Siddhartha Barnhoorn. Out There’s music is gentle and unobtrusive, creating a deceptive calm.

It’s a calm that could be needed, however, as Out There does have the potential to frustrate. The cosmos can be cruel and unforgiving, and the random nature of the game’s universe means that a player’s skill will not always dictate success. Star systems will not always contain gas giants or garden planets, and an unlucky encounter on the way to another system could see severe damage done to the ship hull. If a playthrough is unsuccessful, however, it will not be long before players will want to start another, such is the desire to discover more of the game’s universe.

Out There has translated to home computers with ease, taking on the extra content required in its stride. The title avoids a number of science fiction tropes, and the bold move to avoid combat mechanics gives Out There its own place in space-based video games. Although the gameplay itself may prove tiresome over long periods, the game’s story elements, sense of isolation, and soundtrack make Out There a more-than-worthwhile purchase.

You can improve fuel efficiency and other things all through components. The only down side is some components require others, so that's two slots from your cargo used.

When drilling or probing, you're forced to take or abandon things without having the ability to use my maintenance to fuel or repair your ship. It seems only logical that I deliver hydrogen straight from the probe to my maintenance, but instead I need to jettison something from a full cargo hold.

In terms of anomalies, those are abandon ships, quests or cubes. The cubes will replenish one specific thing whether its fuel, oxygen or your hull. They're very helpful and give you a reason to always live dangerously with low fuel, oxygen or hull hoping to find a cube. Visiting stars themselves will heavily damage your ship and it doesn't seem like there's a use for them unless you get a ship component that lets you fly through a black hole or harvest the power of a white dwarf or something. Other anomalies will wormhole your ship to a different solar system.

When you get to each solar system, sometimes there's a random event will play out through text. Sometimes you're given a choice. Things like you're being attacked, do you hide or flee. Again, there is no combat, so your choice determines does your hull get damaged or do you expend extra fuel escaping? The game recaps what you've gained or lost. With everything playing out via text and the fact that you travel from one star to the next, Out There can feel like a single player board.

The game is beautiful, vivid, colorful backdrops of space, planets and other celestial bodies. It feels spacy with great ambient music and that's all you really need for any space game. Just give a feeling of isolation and gorgeous backdrops. Its a place you can sink a lot of time into.

Depending how far you get, the game will shake things up a bit with hostile aliens that will conquer planets. You won't be able to visit these planets, making a tough game even harder with no difficulty settings.

Now for the major problem that I had, your ship has a radius that you can only jump so far in. About 30 minutes into each play through, I'd come across dead end after dead end. The galactic map never changes, so you can remember your route and where not to go. You need to start relying on random luck to find schematics for worm hole generators or anomalies that will randomly teleport you to places. This makes the game feel unbeatable unless you have luck. Back tracking seems like a brutal death sentence.

For anyone that can get into the game, its a good, relaxing time sink that will keep you playing again and again. There's so much here, but unless you can find a new ship or efficiently manage your fuel, you'll be doomed. That still won't stop you from continuing to explore the outermost galaxies of Out There. I'd like to thank Delphine and Plug In Digital for my copy of the game.

Star Date: Wrote this on Patch 1.1.2 - April 2, 2015

------------------------------------------------------------------

Where am I?: Time for the journey of a lifetime! You have just been thrown into some random star system and your only task is to get to this other, equally random star system in your laughable spaceship. On the way there, pick up upgrades, mine more resources, and meet the locals but try to not get eaten by them. Avoid being stranded in space as you run out of fuel or suffocate in the endless expanses. That's the premise of the game. It's a combination of FTL's spaceship customization but with a much heavier focus on the storyline which serves to be the centerpiece for this game.

------------------------------------------------------------------

Silence is Golden....

(+) Storyline - The storyline is beautifully written. Each time you play and fail and trust me you'll fail a lot, the events you get will be different. What choices you pick will determine what happens to your poor vessel. Exercise some common sense or not because finding out all the ways to die is part of the fun.

(+) The Aliens - Each habitable population that you meet has a vocabulary that changes each iteration but fear not, as you progress in a campaign you'll slowly learn what they are saying. 'No don't give those worms hydrogen fool! Ok let's get out of this planet while we can. Let's look at the bright side, we learned what thb\e word death is in their language and all it cost was these subsystems and hull sections!'

(+) Ship Customization - There's a plethora of ship upgrades to stick on your ship from improving fuel efficiency to shielding during atmospheric landings. Stick the upgrades to the basic modules for an adjacency bonus. The tutorial didn't explain that but I later found out so I'll share it with you guys for reading this far. :)

(+) Resource Management - Gone all the days you can stick 64 stacks of ships, food, tonnages of metals, people, livestock, etc into your pocket. There's a very limited amount of space on each ship that you get. You'll need some space for backup resources to repair your modules and to fuel your ship. That same space gets occupied by cool new techs you'll want to make your ship better. It's a fine balancing act and the game honestly does force you to make tough choices there.

(+) Visuals - The backgrounds to each planet look gorgeous, especially for the volcanic planet.

(+) Price - I can't even buy a large sandwich where I live for $9. For the amount of narrative and gameplay you get, it's definitely worth it.

------------------------------------------------------------------

...but it's maddening as well...

(-) Lack of 'Action' - Ok this one isn't a bit fair but it's more of a warning. Incase you didn't read the game's description, i'll state it one more time - THERE'S NO COMBAT. It's not FTL so don't expect FTL. If you like reading and playing through old-school adventures then this is the game for you. If you're studying for the future starfleet command then you're playing the wrong game.

(-) Tooltips - I tried googling too but some things such as a ship's power, ecosystem,  and resistance. What do they mean? Oh there's an adjacency bonus? I wish the game told me. Some ship upgrades give you a qualitative description of their boost but I want to know the exact numbers please.

------------------------------------------------------------------

Overall, it's a gem for those who like an adventure game that has rogue-like survival elements. The game might get a bit repetitive once you've figured out how much in backup supplies you should carry to reasonably get to the next fueling point but there or once you've read through all the possible ingame events. Nonetheless, it'll be a while before you get to the latter part and for $9, you could do a lot worse. Have fun insulting aliens who you can't understand!

I give it a resounding 7.5 Babbalas out of 10 Rytssalas

reviewText:
A very pretty but profoundly repetitive and underdeveloped game.

The basic gameplay revolves around a route procedure you will repeat throughout the game, and won't really be fundamentally changed much by any tech upgrades you acquire (more on that later). These are as follows:
Travel to the nearest solar system to the bottom-right, and pray that you can reach a yellow system before your oxygen runs out.
Wait for five-second travel cutscene to play out, every single time. (And disable it in the menu after the third jump.)
Handle whatever random event the game throws at you by selecting one of two-four options, most of which will either drain or supply a varying amount of your three resources, or warp you to the other buggering side of the galaxy.
Depending on which of your 0-100 resource counters is lowest, warp to either the gas planet in the system (if your fuel is low) or the rock planet (if your hull strength is low). If your oxygen is low, and you're not in or adjacent to a yellow system, you're dead; hit the convenient 'give up' button and return to step 1. If you still have enough resources to make each little hop, and your equipment isn't fried from the random event you get warping into the system, then congratulations; extract your resource of choice and hope that the RNG gives you more than the resources you spent to get there.
Jump out of the system with whatever generic resources you managed to eke out, or the vain hope that you'll be able to scrounge some in the next system. tl;dr It's interesting for a couple hours while you're still getting a hang of the game, then it just becomes tedious when you're doing the same thing over and over again (fuel + repair).  6/10

I was really psyched to play this game.  Loved FTL and the description of FTL without the combat sounded great.  Unfortunately, it just doesn't come through with any of the depth that FTL had.  It's got atmosphere, absolutely, but that atmosphere is thin and evaporates quickly.  The only way it's a roguelike is in permadeath.  There's not enough variety for me to really consider it a roguelike.

The biggest downfall is the ships.  You start out with a bucket of crap, which is fine and to be expected.  If you're lucky, you might wander across one other ship before the game gives you the second-best ship for free as an auto-reveal plot point.  There's maybe seven or so other ships in the game, but only two of them are actually better than the bucket of crap you started with...which is completely underwhelming.  The firefly, even though it has zero free space, is fun to tool around and explore in simply because everything is so easy -- it's such a relief after the slow-going of the other ships that it can make the game quite fun for a little while.  Otherwise the only major difference is the amount of cargo space.  Even with the biggest ship (21 spaces), you're still going to be very short on space.  If the ships had been at least minimally interesting, I would've enjoyed the game a lot more.

Synergy - while not explained at all - is very important.  If a tech 'requires' another tech, placing it next to the 'required' tech improves the efficiency (giving a blue outline).  Which means less fuel/o2/mining!

The writing is sometimes interesting, but very much amateur hour sci-fi schlock.  Tons of spelling mistakes and awkward transitions.  Every time you warp to a new star, you get a random blurb/encounter.  After going through almost all the stars, I was still seeing new ones, which is something.  If the writing was a bit better, it would be a reason to keep going.  Unfortunately, it's not.  They don't ever really add to the very minimal story.

Drilling/probing should always be done at 10/10.  Ignore the super mining/super probing tech, they're not worth the space or effort.  Get your tech from the alien encounters as soon as you can.  Certain species will always ask approve" others will always ask "disapprove."  If you choose correctly you can get tech and new words.

Overall

Out There provides a unique experience of surviving the elements and fighting with loneliness in outer space. There is no combat, it’s you against the environment. Strong story elements tie this game together with choices that matter, gorgeous art, high replayability, and management mechanics.

Breakdown
This review is written with 8 hours in the PC version (2 hours in beta and 6 hours in full release), plus another 2 hours on the mobile version. I've avoided any major story spoilers.

Area        Rating        Notes                Story        9        The strongest part of the game in my opinion, Out There constantly provides you with short story text describing your journey. Developers state there are 350+ unique text adventures, many with multiple choices with different outcomes (also the choices can be different depending on certain criteria). These are often interesting as it explains a sci-fi event, or reflections of your character as they struggle with their predicament. Some key events are repeated with each playthrough, but with 4 different endings to discover there is a lot of story to get sucked into. The game now also has an opening cutscene of a high production quality, it's nice and short, and gets the story across well.                Gameplay        8.5        The gameplay of Out There can be split into a few different areas but all revolve heavily around decision making. One major area is the management of your ship including what resources to carry for fuel, oxygen. However you need to choose whether building certain components are worth taking more storage space in your ship (ie less fuel to carry for emergencies). Decision making also shines through in the many encounters you have in the game. An example of this is you encounter a cage in space with a creature raging inside of it, do you free it, obeserve it, or leave it. Each has a different outcome. Without giving too much away, there are languages to learn, technologies to use, and ships to board, giving you plenty of unique situations and choices.

reviewText:
Space is a lonely, distant place, especially when you're... out there...
FTL did raw panic, and the sheer urgency of a space based roguelite. Mi-Clos's approach to the genre, and indeed the space based roguelite is to go quite literally in the opposite direction. You do not have time constraints as such, as long as you can keep yourself fuelled, repaired and stocked with oxygen you can bumble around the galaxy as much as you like. Instead, what it provides is a sense of overwhelming scale, and of loneliness. This game is crafted around an uncaring universe, a mind-boggling huge, and often lonely place.

Start at FTL, turn left at the first jump...
The similarities between this and FTL are entirely superficial, you have jump points that you work between, like a spiders web, and jumping between them will burn resources. Like in FTL there's a slew of different spaceships, all with their own idiosyncrasies. That's where the similarities end though, there is no crew in this game, there's only you. There are no weapons to speak of, there are some terraforming tools and a planet killing device which can radically alter the story, but those are special case items. There's no combat, instead you're evading the enemy as you work towards whatever destination you head to, there are no merchants to buy supplies from, instead you're mining and scooping resources and fuel as you go.

You construct your own devices which are then installed into your ship, each device eats up precious cargo space that could be given over to fuel (which you will go through rapidly), repair metals (which you will also go through fairly rapidly) and oxygen (which you will go through less rapidly but you'll come across less often). The game is finely balanced and often you'll find yourself a few jumps away from disaster, where a few bad judgment calls in a row will see your game ended.

And it's not just your ship that is out to kill you...
Even more critically, you start each game with zero knowledge of the alien language, which is randomised each time, so you will learn the words of importance with each encounter, gradually building up your auto-translator and being able to answer their queries and make trades with them as you go further into the galaxy. The very first encounters where you're stumbling over a few words and having to take almost blind guesses based on the positions of the words Love" "Hate" "Death" or "Life" can often lead to unintentional hilarity.

I'm flying through the golden age of comics...
The presentation in this game warrants special mention. Both the graphical design and sound presentation are literally off the scale. The graphics are presented in this retro sci-fi comic book approach

TL;DR Great theme and art spoiled by monotony and a heavy reliance on RNG. Always drill and probe 10/10. Focus is more on resource management than space exploration -- what could be a whismical journey is instead just looking for the next fill up station.

This game... this game would be awesome, if you weren't constantly concerned about finding the next gas giant to fill your tank or hoping you find a garden planet for oxygen. When you do, prepare for some inventory managment so you can stock up!

In the screenshots, the game seems like your main focus would be exploring strange new worlds, encountering life. And at some point in the game, maybe this does happen. But in my 2 hours of playtime, I couldn't manage to get past the first 10 or so galaxy hops. All this game was, in my experience, is drilling planets for materials, probing gas planets for fuel and hoping to the Random Number God that the game would bestow a planet with oxygen at some point so I didn't asphyxiate. Too many of my playthroughs ended simply because the game didn't randomly give me a planet with fuel, or a planet with oxygen. Reading the forums and guides, I do not see how I could have played differently; the game just didn't spawn what I needed, so it was a lost game no matter my choices. DYING TO RNG IS NOT FUN.

The game also has another false choice -- in the beginning, when drilling or probing for materials, the game presents a prompt for how deep you want to go, out of a scale of 10, where the higher number gives more of a chance of your tools breaking. Unless you knew ahead of time, you will waste you time until you find out that you ALWAYS, no matter what, go 10 out of 10. Repairing the tools is less than trivial, so 10/10 is always optimal. If you don't, you simply just waste more fuel and get less materials.

Once you find this truth, the beginning game is monotonous -- you simply hop galaxy to galaxy, consuming planets like Galactus, waiting until the game starts to throw some random event so you can actually start making any sort of decisions. By this point, I was too bored. You still have to hope that the game spawns what you need and doesn't just not give you oxygen until you die. I'd rather have more agency determining the outcome of my run.

reviewText:
This really isn't very good.  I was sure I'd like it based on what I'd read on Rock, Paper, Shotgun, which is why I bought it at launch, but it's more of a chore—one frustratingly sabotaged by luck—than a fun or exciting adventure.

You spend all of your time juggling resources.  You'll sacrifice, for example, fuel and hull for the chance to pick up some oxygen at the rocky planets you come across as you travel along the line of stars between you and your ultimate destination.  You'll keep finding rare elements like tungsten and platinum that you can't use for anything until you discover relevant technologies, but they leave you annoyed at the lack of space in your cargo hold.

You'll meet an alien who gives you the mysterious omega element and decide to throw away your highly common silicon to make room for it, and immediately afterwards you'll chance upon a random event in which robotic termites eat your space folder, leaving you stranded.  If you only had some silicon, you could have repaired it.

There's clearly a story simmering in the background.  You encounter all kinds of zany alien life forms, and a lot of them try to communicate with you.  You gradually pick up some language that might help you to make decisions during these interactions if you actually have a run that lasts long enough, and they're all worried about judges or architects or something.  The writing is the sort that makes you feel like it thinks it's good, like it's really got something to say, but it's actually cringe-worthy much of the time—and badly in need of proofreading, as well.  Here's an example:

Day 63 _

Let's say I find a magic lamp drifting in space and it allows me one wish. What would I wish for?

I must admit to a craving for sausages. Maybe I could return to Earth, but discretely, so I can have some sausages without needing to tell my story a thousand times.

No... My wish would be to find out what I really want.
That's terrible, right?  Come on.  It's hard to care when the writing is that bad.

So there's really nothing compelling me to continue playing this.  I guess I'm curious to see what it's like to have a nice ship decked out with a bunch of tech that makes life easier, collecting rare elements and building interesting new devices, but getting there is a matter of pure luck.  There's no progress between runs that helps your goal to seem more plausible, either.

Everything that I manage to discover before inevitably running out of fuel after desperately traveling to the nearest fuel-rich gas giant that the game tells me on arrival has nothing left to probe—all of the technologies and new ship types (with their ample, blessed cargo space) that I've found along the way are gone.  I haven't unlocked anything that makes the crapshoot of space travel more manageable next time.

One of the game's selling points is that it has no combat; it's just you against the environment.  Well, maybe if it did have combat I'd actually feel like I have some control over what happens.  The idea of a game without combat appeals to me!  But it needs to be better designed than this.

Out There is no FTL.  There's no real strategy that you can employ as you play to have a greater chance of success.  In the moment-to-moment gameplay, it's just dull, while in the grand scheme of a full session it's frustrating.  Pass on this.

reviewText:
Running out of fuel: The game.
This is a mixed review.

The game is solid at what it focuses on: environment and isolation. The scenery and soundtrack are both enjoyable and engrossing, while the challenge of surviving alone in an indifferent universe will engage you for many hours.

Where the game fails however is in the execution of the resource management and randomized systems. Limited cargo space makes stockpiling difficult, while the sparsity of gas giants for fuel makes it all but impossible to actually net fuel in the long run. I've had games where I had 3 stacks of stockpiled fuel and a full tank and I lose anyway because the next series of systems I visited had no sources of fuel. Games. Plural.

In 30+ games I've yet to get more than halfway to the target systems at the far end of the map and that was only because an event teleported me much closer (only to leave me stranded because I didn't have the jump distance systems to get out of the cluster). I can understand some difficulty, but the journal entries, encounters, and events start feeling stale and repetitive after seeing them the second or third time in a playthrough because you've not gotten that golden game where everything goes right.

This is compounded by some UI oddities that stem from the game's mobile origin. Lack of many simple shortcuts makes for tedious management of things. To get more fuel you send out the Hydrogen Probe and it returns with whatever it found. Rather than being able to put it directly into your tank from this screen, you have to switch over to the ship view and drop it into the fuel tank there before switching back over to the planet screen to probe for more fuel. Rather than a button to empty everything from a probe or drill or double clicking to transfer to cargo, everything is drag and drop or rightclick to select transfer to cargo (then watch the game drag and drop it for you, meanwhile you can do nothing but wait for it). Normally these wouldn't be an issue in a game, but when you're doing this a dozen times at every gas giant you go exploring for fuel, it gets massively tedious.

Abandoned ships you encounter are often side-grades from the shuttle you start in. The few ships that are larger have oddties or are in need of serious repairs before you can use the extra space they afford; the few ships that are smaller only amplify the resource storage problem.

The technologies you find are interesting to find but don't help much and are an uncommon find if you don't get lucky with finding the right tech and the resources for it. The new modules save a small portion of your resources by taking up space where you could have stored them in the first place. I imagine finding three or four would actually make for a much more efficient ship, but again the problem is luck in finding them.

I will likely continue to play to try to find some closure for the plot, but as it stands for me I don't hold much hope of ever finding it. Such is the drawback of random generation and encounters: Some players don't get lucky.

Despite these flaws it is a solid game of exploration and resource management. I encountered no bugs or glaring issues while playing. If you enjoy exploration and atmospheric games, grab a touchscreen and this will be an enjoyable experience for many hours.

If I wanted to play space adventure games, I'd play FTL.
Not that Out There has anything to do with it. But I really hope I'd purchased FTL first.
Out There has an interesting concept, but will ultimately be cause for stress, anger and depression.

It's not a graphics issue, those are fine. Nothing too special and definitely not ugly. Some visuals (that of the black hole, for example) are actually quite beautiful.
It's not an idea issue, that -aside from the fact that it might even be TOO developed, for the depth then delivered by the game-, is fine. The story...makes sense, there is some interesting variety and you do, in the end, want to figure out the hidden secrets of the game.

It's the GAME. I'm not the best player in the world, and not one to ragequit on a game that's too hard. Seriously: most of my games are unfinished because I tend to suck at most. But this is just frustrating. Pretty much everything you do causes damage, and because of the little cargo space of the ship, you either suffocate, explode or get stuck in the middle of deep space. OR YOU DON'T experiment. That's an option, of course. You can survive long enough, if you just ignore every material you find, every technology you discover, every planet you'd like to land on. The moment you pick up something new, bang, you're dead.

And guess what, it's all back to the start, baby. Took me half a dozen time before I told this little game to ♥♥♥♥ right off. I wonder how many times it'll take you.

reviewText:
Out There is a very atmospheric rouge-like game. It's suprisingly interesting and definitely worth a look.

Video Review:

https://youtu.be/wAlsEgo3wq8

What is it?

Out There is a science fiction rouge-like game. You play as an astronaut who has mysteriously arrived deep in space after waking from cryo sleep. You're goal is to travel to one of multiple objective points on the star map. In order to survive the journey you need to harvest fuel, metals, and oxygen along the way.

The gameplay is very reminiscent of FTL in cetrain areas. The main map consists of star systems that you can jump between. Once you're at a system you can travel to the planets to mine them for rescources and potentially find technology. Between each new star system you get a random event where you have make choices, often with limited knowledge that can hurt or benefit you.

The game focuses on the feelings of lonliness and exploration that your character feels while he is traveling. You have to try to communicate with aliens and in the process begin to learn their language. The atmosphere is built as a beautiful combination of lonliness and exploration. Everything is new and alien, but that adventure doesn't take away from the fact that there is no one to share the stories with.

Unlike other rouge-likes, there is no way to change what you start with. You always begin with the same ship and you can only get others by happening upon them in your travels. Each ship has its own benefits and drawbacks (although your first ship is really a hunk of junk).

Pros:

-Every game will be very different. You're coices will be storngly driven by whatever ship or technologies you find first.

-Immersive atmosphere. The soundtrack, the text, and the visuals all work together to build on that atmosphere.

-The game focuses heavily on its rescource managment side and does it well. It doesn't burden itself with a combat system (which could be a con for some, but a I think this game did it well). You will often dread dropping that tungsten, but you have to to make room for fuel.

-Multiple endings. I've only one once so far, but I've seen at least four different objectives that one could go to.

-Games can be quick. I think that my average game was about thirty minutes going to as long as an hour.

Cons:

-Grindy. The gameplay can end up feeling a bit grindy as you fly between rocky planets and gas giants just probing them all day. Despite this, I didn't hate the grind as much as I might in other games.

-Potenitally simple endings.  The one ending that I have achieved was the first objective you are given. When I got to the star I spoke to the Architects, an old race of aliens that keep the universe working. All that happened was that my character figured out that he was the last human and then flew off into the stars to try to resurect his people. I didn't get any choice in the matter and the game ended. I don't know if this is how other endings work, but it's food for thought.

-It can feel unfair at times. I've had instances when I go to three gas giants, troll them for fuel, and can't even recoup the fuel I spent getting there. There wasn;t any obvious reason why and it is a bit frustrating.

-All progress is lost after you die. I like rouge-likes that reward you for doing awsome things (like winning the game) by giving you something that you can start the game with. FTL's version of that was new ships and layouts. Out There doesn't have any of that.

Overall, Out There is a really fun game. I have thoroughly enjoyed my time with it so far. It's more than worth $10, especially if you love exploration.

reviewText:
Pros:
Beautiful graphics/illustrations. It's like FTL, but prettier.
Lots of interesting story elements.

Cons:
The game gets repetitive too quickly. While the story has constanly new and different elements, even that loses its flavor after awhile, because unlike FTL, which had more immediacy to it... there is very little driving force to push you forward. Your focus is to keep your ship going... but you are severely limited in how you can do that,

The new technologies you can discover seem neat at first, until you realize they don't tend to do all that much differently or improve the gameplay all that much. Your ship is extremely limited. You can actually discover new ships, apparently, which does improve things, but there is no garuntee of this and the existing ship has very little space in it. It seems like poor design decisions led to combining your cargo with the slots to install your new tech in. I don't recall you ever being limited in cargo in FTL and that is one of my big gripes here. Plus, in FTL, you could easily expand various capabilities of your ship beyond just new tech you can install. The tech seems more varied in Out There, but also far more limited.

Having to micromanage your cargo space is annoying, because while all the elements you can find have info on them, most of these elements are pretty much useless unless you stumble across the right technology that requires these elements to build.

Also, if you go to a breathable atmosphere planet and immediately fill up your O levels, why can you not also fill up as much inventory of O as possible? I would have to drill for it, and still too often get too little. The balance of elements to drill or probe for seems out of whack. Also, more often than not, it seemed like a waste to drill or probe a second time, as it produced little to nothing in addition. I would think drilling 2-3 times could still yield some good resources, at least more often than not. Otherwise, why is there an option to drill or probe a second time other than to waste your resources? Just make it only doable once and be done with it.

I played through three times, and got better each time, but mainly, I stuck very strictly to doing very specific things, because otherwise, it is way too easy to run out of resources in this game.

FINAL SUM UP:
I think if I didn't have such limited cargo space and the elements were not quite so out of whack when drilling... the game would play better for me. It is in many ways a more laid back kind of game compared to FTL, which has combat and the risk of being attacked if you explore too much... and I want to like this game for the graphics and story, but it seems like there isn't enough of a game to really make it worth more than a few playthroughs. Maybe if there was more story that a player can actively get involved with, but it is all so passive, almost like a visual novel you can die in and have to do a little bit of work in, but mostly, just... yeah.

So I cannot really recommend it... very lightly, very mixed. .

reviewText:
I generally do enjoy the game, but the inventory system is a problem, as it's a problem in every game that tries to bodge a clumsily restrictive tile inventory together. Music's perfect, atmosphere's evocative, art is simple while suiting the game well, but the design isn't quite there for me to recommend this game without reservation. Still largely worth a buy, I'd say. And if you don't like it, get a refund - easy.

Edit: I'm going to change this to a no simply because there are too many design shortcomings that negatively impact the experience. The inventory is a major factor in the way it paints you into a corner or creates arbitrary crises simply through bad design. I don't mind losing in a difficult but fair game, but the game wasting my time because it's poorly designed is inexcusable.

I'll give an example: in the course of the game you need to gather and stock various rare elements (like gold, thorium, platinum, etc.) in order to build and repair some of the more exotic ship modules. Good so far. The problem is that the ships you're flying will generally tend to be between 14-16 tiles, with a good 2/3 of those taken up by essential ship hardware, leaving maybe 6-7 to store cargo in. You want to be stocking full 20-stacks of essentials like iron, hydrogen, oxygen, or helium if you can get your hands on it, but rare elements you only use for repairs, or the omega element that's essentially a wild card, all MUST take up an entire cargo hold even if you only have 1. So if you have 1 omega, 3 hafnium, 3 gold, 8 thorium, and 5 platinum, that's FIVE of your 6 cargo holds used for storing crumbs of rare elements that you need to mitigate RNG with. In a sane world these crumbs (that incidentally total up to 20) would only take up one tile of space. Where's the iron, helium, hydrogen, and oxygen going to fit? Nowhere. Something needs to go overboard, and sure enough, as soon as you dump it, you'll get a random event that requires the element you threw away. It's like the developers, or all the people giving this game awards, never bothered to play it.

This is 3/4 of a good game, with the last quarter being lazily programmed and amateurishly designed garbage, as is distressingly common with a lot of these games that rely on their music, writing, or art direction to draw people in, like Don't Starve, Sunless Sea, and several other overrated culprits. It's like going to a restaurant with attractive ambiance, a great band, and being served a perfectly arranged meal that tastes like cat vomit.

Developers, fix your ♥♥♥♥in' game; it isn't too late. This game is already highly modular and begging to be expanded on (orbiting derelicts, trade posts, maybe a little space combat hazard to use the Resistance stat, stealth - emission sinks, etc.). An inventory fix, and fixes for a few other imperfections, would be just the thing to throw in there.

Procedurally generated space roguelikes are few and far between, this game is actually quite unique in what it does. In FTL what will kill you is a missile or sweeping laser hitting you at a bad time, where as in 'Out There' what will get you killed is a decision you made ten turns ago. Like say thinking that you will be good without keeping that common-as-dirt iron cluttering your ship's hold  or thinking you have plenty of fuel to make another jump.

'Out There' is like slow moving chess, with quiet dreamy music and little vignettes. It is the first game I've played in a long while that emphasized the exploration part of game play and it is a refreshing change. Even talking to aliens is a neat little mystery as you have to guess what they are trying to say and as you go along learning little snippets of language and the backstory as it unfolds.

There are fun little jabs of humor and it would be relaxing if you weren't on the knife edge of survival at every instant. You can see gameplay elements in managing your ship's resources. You'll be thinking about fuel, oxygen and whatever rare metal dugup and trying to make sophie's choice on which to abandon and which to carry on the chance you might get a technology to use it. Make no mistake this is a rogue like, a pretty, quiet, sedate one but still a roguelike and you will die many many many times.

It is an interesting reversal of the normal formula. The game is at its most random in the start when you have nothing and a bad roll of the dice can doom you on turn two. But if you can just last long enough to find a good technology, or a new ship, or a lucky streak of events you start to get a lot more options and agency. It is thrilling to get to that point, to get into a good routine.. then it becomes your own damn fault if you got greedy and risky.

Gas planets have fuel; oxygenated planets have air and life and metals and one form of fuel (carbon); rocky planets have metals and carbon. You discover technologies as you jump from solar system to solar system through random events. (You can also lose tech through random events: ex. space bugs chewing through part of you computer causes it to lose the info on how to build a certain tech. The randomness of the gift of tech and space ships and life forms that all have their own advantages and disadvantages. Life forms give you gifts randomly or by saying and giving them all the right things. They have a randomly generated language (every time the game is restarted). reviewText:
There are no space battles, instead this game excels at what it does: pushing your decision making skills to the edge for survival. In FTL you might be deciding now and then whether to buy more hull hitpoints, fuel or another crewmember, and that will keep you alive for another sector or so (hopefully). In Out There you'll have to decide whether another jump to a planet with metals instead (costing fuel) won't kill you because the next jump's random event suddenly drains your fuel so much and the planets there (and possibly that of the next two jumps) are completely impossible to recover from.

This may sound unnecessarily punishing, but at some point you can get the hang of it (it's just a tough pill to swallow if you thought you could build up some kind of comfort zone). After some failures I could see how there's really that need for optimizing every decision towards maximum survival possibilities, and for example forcing me to have to deal with my habit of loot hoarding. It took me a while to figure out that demolishing ship parts to rebuild them later can grant extra logistical options, and how to take the expense of such actions into account through those tough decisions you have to make. I still fail miserably at it, but that's just testament to how well this game is designed around the deep drive for survival.

I'd say, abstract thinkers and problem solvers alike may like this game very much, it's more of a puzzle from some points of view, but the theme is still there, very well integrated into the gameplay. If you are more into the action that FTL's space battles granted, I'm afraid you won't find it here. This game pushes you to the limits just as much, but to the sense of a more strategic view on things, rather than tactically. And you need it, to survive in space, you need to do everything to extend your potential lifespan because space is scary like that, and this game conveys that just perfect.

Masterfully crafted in my opinion, deceptively simple and punishing, but keeps you coming back for more.

reviewText: Dear Lord I Hope I Find Fuel Simulator 2015

I purchased this game on a whim (steam sale 50% off) and it was one ofthe better decisions I have made as far as purchases go recently. I would gladly pay full price for this game knowing what I know now: this game is fantastic. It is very simple, yet extremely complex. You have a ship which needs fuel, air, and metal to survive. (Fuel to move, air to breath, metal to repair the ship). You collect these resources from different planets you encounter. Planets are in various solar systems you travel to. Gas planets have fuel; oxygenated planets have air and life and metals and one form of fuel (carbon); rocky planets have metals and carbon. You discover technologies as you jump from solar system to solar system through random events. (You can also lose tech through random events: ex. space bugs chewing through part of you computer causes it to lose the info on how to build a certain tech. If that tech is destroyed you won't be able to rebuild it if you don't re-discover the tech). This is what makes the game so addicting. The randomness of the gift of tech and space ships and life forms that all have their own advantages and disadvantages. Life forms give you gifts randomly or by saying and giving them all the right things. They have a randomly generated language (every time the game is restarted). Learned words are always the same every time you restart. So, whatever languages you learned with this current space explorer's life, you will have for his duration. Once you die, everything beins anew. I just beat the game- finally- and I plan on replaying it much more. Why? Because I only got one of the endings! There is so much more I have left out, but I think this is adequate enough to pique some of your interests. Note: the game is very tough due to the randomness. If you can have things fall your way until you find a bigger ship and gather some useful tech then you will increase your chance of survival exponentially. (I went from lasting maybe 20 or so solar systems explored to over 100 in my last playthrough).

I loved the art and atmosphere Out There provides.  However, it is essentially a luck driven game.  The penalties you receive by random chance are devastating; the cost to travel, drill, probe, etc is too high or the ability to stockpile resources is too low.  Ultimately, it just becomes a dice roll.  Sometimes you'll survive through 30 star systems, sometime as low as 3.  Play enough times and you'll get somewhere, but very little will do with skill (although some base knowledge of resource management is needed).  This game is not for explorers, this game is for masochists who don't mind starting over after no real fault of their own.  A save option might fix this so you can reroll" those fickle dice of fate.  I would also probably enjoy an option to bump up the cargo storage (like double or triple)."

Out There is a game I was really excited about when I stumbled on it a few days ago.  I was expecting a game like FTL, but with its own unique style.  It does have a unique style, but the gameplay is severely lacking.  Resource management is much more complicated than it needs to be.  You constantly run out of everything.  Running out of any one of the games three resources--fuel, hull, and oxygen--leads to an immediate game over.  Space on your starting ship is very limited, and you will constantly find yourself destroying and rebuilding modules to make more space for resources.  Game overs are frequent because you can run out of resources at any time if you hit several systems that lack planets to resupply at.  Game overs are far too frequent.

The game itself is unrewarding.  Unlike FTL, there are no unlockable ships.  You can find ships randomly during your adventure, but there is no way to start the game with a different ship.  Different ships require different materials to repair and maintain, which means you can stumble upon great ships that need materials you don't have because you never have enough space to carry them.  Not being able to unlock different starting ships makes the game stale as it limits your options.

Technology gains are also completely random, and whole sections of the map later become inaccessible later in the game if you haven't stumbled upon certain required technologies.  Even after you acquire the design for a technology (which can be lost in random events), you still must build it, often out of resources you can't keep on hand because of space limitations.  And for every technology you add to your ship, you have less space to gather materials.

The map of stars is fixed, but the planets and events are randomized.  This may sound like enough variation to keep the game fresh, but the lack of choice made the game stale for me after a few dozen attempts.  There are four different endings, but nothing that any of them offer could compel me to play further.  There is too little strategy, too little choice, and too much chance.

There are makings of a good game here.  The art and music are both excellent, and the production values are high, and it does have some interesting ideas.  It's just poorly balanced and unrewarding.  Making ships unlockable (so that you could choose to focus on different materials and have more freedom) would be a welcome change.  If a sequel is made that addresses my complaints, I will be the first in line to buy it.  But I cannot in any way recommend this game in its current state.

This game is just about an exercise in futility. Is it impossible to win, no, but the chances are extremely slim and rely on both planning and lots of luck. But something about this extreme difficulty is what really makes this game have charm. You play an astronaut who has been out for who knows how long, as far as we know Earth and humanity may be wiped out and you may be the last of your kind. The ominous fear adds to the basic principal of what ha made humanity humanity. We have always struggled against the impossible when there was no hope, in examples like the ice age, the black plague, and global warfare, even in the bleakest of times we continue on and that is the reason we still exist today. This game carries the same spirit of knowing you're going to die and yet you try to push as far as you can before that happens because you have hope to see the end.

So yes this game is hard, this game is unfair, and you know you're going to die, that's what makes it charming. add the log entries, the random situations, being stranded in uncharted space encountering creatures you can't understand and not knowing what dangers lie around the next star jump, that struggle for survival just eminates throughout the whole game. Beautifully conveyed in both audio and visual forms, the game is relaxing and enchanting to both look at and listen to.

Give it a chance, and understand that this game is an experience in what it means to be human, not just another title to buy and beat.

Out There: Omega Edition puts you in the position of an astronaut whose normal shuttle flight and cryo-sleep doesn't go as planned, and a simple trip finds him in an unknown part of the galaxy, with a mysterious faster-than-light drive, and a signal calling him to a far star system.  You're in the unknown with limited cargo, and a vague idea of what's going on.

Simple point-and-click navigation lets you travel to various star systems and explore the planets therein.  However every choice costs valuable resources - fuel, oxygen, and hull integrety.  You've got to balance what you choose to do carefully to keep yourself alive.

As you explore, you'll encounter various worlds.  Some will have oxygen and life, letting you restock supplies and perhaps gain some insight or resources from the inhabitants (which also requires you to learn an alien language).  Others may be rich in minerals, providing elements you need to craft new gear.  Yet others are gas giants, providingr fuel for the journey.  Exploring may lead you to mysterious artifacts, ancient ruins, abandoned ships, black holes, random events, and more.  You're never quite sure what's around the corner - though the right equipment may help you avoid (or find) surprises.

Crafting and repairing equipment is a large part of the game.  One broken piece of technology -or one new device - may make the difference between life and death.  Some technologies radically change your ship's capabilities, and some can be paired to enhance their functions.  You might find yourself mining - or scavenging - just to try out something new.

You'll also find different spacecraft if you're fortunate, providing you even more options for exploration.  Some of them are wildly different and highly imaginative - and may or may not be what you're looking for in your travels.

On top of all of this there's an interesting plot with multiple possible endings for you to try and reach depending on your inclinations.  The entire package combines into a fascinating, engaging adventure - each move, each decision, requires some thought and planning.
